results.title: Canberra today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: The rapidly developing capital city of Australia. Its beautiful site and many parks and gardens; national traditions enshrined in the Australian War Memorial, the Royal Military College of Duntroon and in Parliament House. The diplomatic missions, Canberra University College, research institutions. The corporate life of the city and plans for its future.

results.brief_description: Gives impressions of Australia’s national capital and the life of its inhabitants. Shows government buildings and other architectural features, but emphasises the merits of the pace of life, climate and scenery.

results.brief_description: Looks at Canada the country - the people and their way of life, the industries, physical description, the cities, farming areas, transport and communication.

results.title: Canada's Provinces and people
results.brief_description: Canada, a country with a great variety of landforms and people of many ethnic backgrounds, is emerging as a leader in world trade and has become one of the most prosperous nations of the world. Emphasises the relation of Canada’s natural resources to the lives of the people. Individual regions are mapped with their primary industries.

results.title: Canada's prairie Provinces
results.brief_description: A revealing look at Canada’s heartland. Traditional occupations of wheat farming, cattle raising and lumbering are shown with new occupations created by technology. Harnessing of rivers has brought irrigation and electric power for manufacturing. New industries plus discovery of oil, uranium and other minerals are changing life in the Prairie Provinces.

results.title: Canada's Pacific Province and northland
results.brief_description: Highlights the Pacific Province and northern lands of Canada - British Columbia, the Yukon Territory and the North-west Territories, their historical development and the backgrounds of their people. The land, climate, natural resources and the importance of farming, fishing and lumbering are shown.

results.title: Canada's history: colony to commonwealth
results.brief_description: Canada’s history, from a colony torn by internal strife to a strong, independent nation. French and English exploration; French traders and settlements, growth of English settlement in North America; conflict over the control of the land; the war between the French and the English; English governors appointed to govern a predominantly French Catholic people. James Murray Hadden and Guy Carleton who both worked toward French equality, Carleton’s work in parliament resulting in the Quebec Act of 1774, which settled many of the French-English differences to Quebec.
results.description: Canada’s history, from a colony torn by internal strife to a strong, independent nation. French and English exploration; French traders and settlements, growth of English settlement in North America; conflict over the control of the land; the war between the French and the English; English governors appointed to govern a predominantly French Catholic people. James Murray Hadden and Guy Carleton who both worked toward French equality, Carleton’s work in parliament resulting in the Quebec Act of 1774, which settled many of the French-English differences to Quebec.

results.title: Canada's central Provinces
results.brief_description: This film explores Canada’s most industrialised and mechanised provinces: the variety of geographic regions, the people involved in various farming and industrial activities and life in the major cities. The early history is traced and the contrast between French-influenced Quebec and British-influenced Ontario is highlighted.

results.title: Canada's Atlantic Provinces
results.brief_description: Surrounded by the ocean, dotted with inland lakes and rivers, water plays a major role in the four provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland, whose inhabitants are mainly of French and British origin. Many of the people continue to lead isolated lives adequately supporting themselves by farming, fishing and lumbering.
